And this method is designed to mimic the pressure of a real conversation but in a totally controlled way.
So how did it work? Just asking and answering questions.
Yes. But with a very important rule.
He'd ask himself a simple question like what did you do today and then answer it. The secret ingredient was forced elaboration.
Forced elaboration. So he couldn't just give a short answer.
No, he had to force himself to add complexity and detail. So the first answer might be, I worked  simple enough.
But the next time he practiced, it had to be longer. I worked on my project for 3 hours.

Yep. Worked on my project for three hours. Then I took a break and had some coffee and talked to my friend.

So, strategy 5 brings the focus back to refinement, specifically pronunciation and sounding more natural.
This was the echo technique. Another 30 minutes of dedicated practice every day.
So, how is this different from the copying sentences thing he did in the first 15 days?
The first one was about building the basic muscle memory for tone. The echo technique is more about real-time execution and really, really deep
listening.
Okay. So, what's the process?
He would listen to a native speaker from a movie, a podcast, anything. And he would pause the audio after each full sentence
and then just repeat it.
And repeat it exactly the same speed, the same tone, the same emotion, every detail. So the goal is to train your ear
to catch those tiny subtle things native speakers do without thinking.
Precisely the reductions the way words link together. For example, a native speaker doesn't say I do not know. They say I don't know.
Right. And he had to repeat the sound I don't know, not the written words.
That's the key. And after a month of doing this for 30 minutes every day, he said that's when people started telling
him his English sounded really natural  because he wasn't just using the right words anymore. He was using the right
music. the music of the language. That is the critical distinction. You can have perfect grammar, perfect vocabulary, but if your rhythm and
intonation are wrong, you still sound foreign.
The echo technique fixes the music,  and the music is often what makes people understand you easily and feel comfortable talking to you.
Okay, next up is vocabulary. He knew that memorizing lists of words was useless for him. The words never stuck,
right? So he came up with strategy six, the story method.
This sounds interesting.
It's based on a simple truth about our brains. We remember things better when they are in a story, when they have context and emotion.
So what was his system?
Simple but brilliant. He'd take five new words every day. Then he would create a short, simple story that used all five of those words.
And then of course he would read that story out loud 10 times.
Always reading it out loud. Let's use his example. The words are excited, invitation, party, arrive, and surprise.
Okay.
So, instead of just writing definitions, he created a narrative. I was very excited because I received an invitation
to a big party. When I arrived at the party, I got a huge surprise. It was my birthday party.
That makes so much sense. By putting them in a story, you're forced to understand how they work together, the grammar, the context.
You know, if it's a noun or a verb, what prepositions go with it. He estimated he learned over a thousand new words this
way in about three months and they were words he could actually use.
All these intense tactics, they all feed into the big one. Strategy seven, training the brain to think in English.

Prepositions.

So, he created a system for it, a small notebook just for confusing prepositions.

Number five, expand vocabulary smartly.
